metadata.pr_title: Improve "Enter Office" UX when it fails.
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/PDCT-536/improve-enter-office-ux

This PR enhances the user availability status change functionality by adding loading states and error handling when users change their status. Especially useful for edge-cases.

![Screenshot 2025-07-30 at 03.12.08.png](https://graphite-user-uploaded-assets-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/6t9RbkvcqpZpnH98hrsY/eb4f25c6-ab7c-454a-abf5-9451e9d954a9.png)

![Screenshot 2025-07-30 at 03.12.18.png](https://graphite-user-uploaded-assets-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/6t9RbkvcqpZpnH98hrsY/2f6140f5-5f23-4248-bb73-31e0710840b9.png)

### Details

- Added loading state to the "Enter office" button
  - Prevents multiple clicks while a status change is in progress
- Implemented robust error handling in the `SpaceUserAvailabilityPresenter`
  - Added connection verification before attempting to change status
  - Added error reporting and user notifications when status changes fail
  - Added performance monitoring for slow status changes
- Refactored availability methods to use a common implementation
  - Reduces code duplication
  - Ensures consistent error handling across all status changes

### Test Plan

- [x] Test changing status while connected (Active, Busy, Away)
- [x] Test changing status while disconnected: validate loading spinner appears
- [x] Verify error toast appears when status change fails

properties.Project Description:
Includes:
- Member option to Auto DND if you have a non-Gather meeting link in the location field of your connected calendar (e.g., Zoom, Meet, etc.)  
- Admin option to remove people from the office after X hours of inactivity (configurable)

See Auto DND [prototype](https://www.figma.com/proto/9wqJprIW5h52E4Pdplb32T/Auto-dnd-%26-leave-office?page-id=0%3A1&type=design&node-id=195-50518&viewport=-34%2C-3850%2C0.22&t=zC7RAuN3use2ZMww-9&scaling=min-zoom&starting-point-node-id=195%3A50518&show-proto-sidebar=1) and [specs](https://www.figma.com/file/9wqJprIW5h52E4Pdplb32T/Auto-dnd-%26-leave-office?type=design&node-id=0-1&mode=design) & Auto Leave Figma file [here](https://www.figma.com/file/9wqJprIW5h52E4Pdplb32T/Auto-dnd-%26-leave-office?type=design&node-id=231-69745&mode=design).
properties.Rollout Plan: Test each on staging and roll out each when ready. We may decouple Auto-DnD and Leave Office for roll-out depending on readiness.

2/8/2024: Initial (high level) functional requirements have been defined ([here](https://gather-town.slack.com/archives/C06GW9SCRK9/p1707437164266599?thread_ts=1707436626.553709&cid=C06GW9SCRK9)). Design and Eng scoping are TBD.

metadata.pr_title: Implement SpotifyUserMediaStatusService to track media status.
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/VW-4052/implement-now-playing-poller-and-model

Implement Spotify "Now Playing" feature to display users' currently playing music in Gather

### Details

- Added `SpotifyUserMediaStatusService` to poll Spotify API for users' currently playing music
  - Maintains a queue of online users with connected Spotify accounts
  - Polls each user in a round-robin fashion with adaptive polling intervals
  - Updates user media status when music is playing or clears it when not playing
- Added `SpotifyClient` to handle Spotify API interactions
  - Fetches currently playing track information
  - Handles token refresh when authentication expires
- Enhanced `ServerSpaceUserMediaStatusRepo` with methods to:
  - Update media status from Spotify data
  - Clear media status when needed
- Updated `ServerSpotifyOAuthUserSecretRepo` to:
  - Register user secrets with the media status service
  - Unregister user secrets when disconnected

### Test Plan

- [x] Connect Spotify account to Gather
- [x] Play music on Spotify and verify it appears in Gather
- [x] Pause music and verify the status is cleared
- [x] Disconnect Spotify account and verify the status is cleared
- [x] Verify status updates when changing songs
- [x] Test with multiple users to ensure round-robin polling works correctly

metadata.pr_title: [CHAT-618] - fix join/leave channel messages
metadata.pr_body:
### Details
We stopped sending the chat message and metadata over the join/leave events because now we fetch channel messages when a user clicks into the channel, but that also means we are no longer sending the join/leave system messages. This PR returns the join/eave message and metadata up from the `addChannelMember` and `removeChannelMembers` methods so that the respective calling controllers can broadcast the system message out via `broadcastNewMessage`

### Test Plan

- Join/leave a channel and verify that the system message is sent to the channel without a refresh
- As an admin, invite/kick a user out of a channel and verify the system message is sent to the channel without refresh

metadata.pr_title: consolidate availability change and hide notice
metadata.pr_body:
This stack is trying to accomplish the following:
- Update naming conventions to reflect what's in the [autobusy figjam](https://www.figma.com/board/f7Z4reblXZjwOBkribS2G6/Auto-Busy-for-External-Video-Calls?t=lTbSXFqPQ50KRYD1-0). Specifically we've split out autobusy from the external meeting flow. Autobusy means we automatically nav a user to a meeting room when an external meeting is detected. External meeting flow means a calendar event with an external meeting link will force participants to flip to busy + redirect to an external meeting provider.
- Add tests that cover behaviour E2E or when autobusy is turned off
- Fix a bunch of bugs to make behaviour feel more predictable

Consolidate hiding notice in one place (by reacting to availability change)

### Test Plan

- [x] Mark this box if automated tests would suffice for the test plan (preferred)

metadata.pr_title: Track different MapObject behaviors via an enum in the model.
metadata.pr_body:
### Details

This PR properly fixes the bug that was mitigated downstream.

The bug was related to how we were checking for which behavior was active: before, we simply checked which of the ValueObjects in `MapObjectBehaviors` model was `not undefined`. However, this doesn't work because of the way ValueObjects work and the data that we have in them.

`ValueObject` works by inlining all of its internal data as fields directly in the `Model` that uses it. For example: the `X` and `Y` of a `Position` ValueObject is inlined side-by-side as 2 new separate columns in the `SpaceUser` model.

The problem with the current `MapObjectBehaviors` is that both `githubWorkloadTrackerBehaviorSchema` and `gongBehaviorSchema` are *empty* (have no internal data), so there are no fields to add to the model table.

Additionally, Gather's platform code is powered by MobX, and so each field (even the optional ones) are actually MobX proxies.

Therefore, what ends up happening is that both Github and Gong ValueObjects are empty (because they have no data), but are defined (because they are actually a MobX object, proxying to an empty object).

The fix is to have another field which tells exactly what is the expected behavior.

- Added `mapObjectBehaviorTemplate` enum field to `MapObjectBehaviors` model
  - Allows explicit tracking of which behavior template is active on a map object
  - Default value is `GithubTracker` for backward compatibility with existing behaviors
- Added `resetBehavior()` method to clear all behaviors when switching types
- Updated behavior addition methods to set the appropriate template enum value
- Improved behavior detection functions to use the template enum instead of checking for behavior existence
  - `isGithubWorkloadTrackerMapObject` now checks the template enum
  - `isGongMapObject` now properly detects Gong behaviors using the template enum

### Test Plan

- [x] Create a map object with a GitHub tracker behavior and verify it's correctly identified
- [x] Create a map object with a Gong behavior and verify it's correctly identified
- [x] Verify existing map objects with behaviors continue to work correctly with the migration

metadata.pr_title: Improve "Enter Office" UX when it fails.
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/PDCT-536/improve-enter-office-ux

This PR enhances the user availability status change functionality by adding loading states and error handling when users change their status. Especially useful for edge-cases.

![Screenshot 2025-07-30 at 03.12.08.png](https://graphite-user-uploaded-assets-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/6t9RbkvcqpZpnH98hrsY/eb4f25c6-ab7c-454a-abf5-9451e9d954a9.png)

![Screenshot 2025-07-30 at 03.12.18.png](https://graphite-user-uploaded-assets-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/6t9RbkvcqpZpnH98hrsY/2f6140f5-5f23-4248-bb73-31e0710840b9.png)

### Details

- Added loading state to the "Enter office" button
  - Prevents multiple clicks while a status change is in progress
- Implemented robust error handling in the `SpaceUserAvailabilityPresenter`
  - Added connection verification before attempting to change status
  - Added error reporting and user notifications when status changes fail
  - Added performance monitoring for slow status changes
- Refactored availability methods to use a common implementation
  - Reduces code duplication
  - Ensures consistent error handling across all status changes

### Test Plan

- [x] Test changing status while connected (Active, Busy, Away)
- [x] Test changing status while disconnected: validate loading spinner appears
- [x] Verify error toast appears when status change fails

metadata.pr_title: major refactor
metadata.pr_body:
## Summary

This is a major refactor that introduces a comprehensive knowledge management system and reorganizes the documentation structure to improve AI agent capabilities and session management.

## Key Changes

### 🧠 Knowledge Management System
- **New `/knowledge` directory structure** for persistent learning and memory storage
- **Repository-specific knowledge tracking** with `knowledge/repos/ORG/REPO/` structure  
- **Deployment token integration** for direct knowledge updates via $KNOWLEDGE_UPDATE_TOKEN
- **Automated knowledge persistence** across sessions with structured learning documentation

### 📚 Documentation Restructuring  
- **Moved `docs/ai/mcp-tools.mdc` → `docs/mcp-tools.mdc`** for better accessibility
- **New reference system** with centralized formatting guidelines in `docs/references.mdc`
- **Session management documentation** in `docs/what-is-a-session.mdc`
- **Knowledge usage guidelines** in `docs/how-to-use-knowledge.mdc`

### 🔧 Workflow Improvements
- **Enhanced GitHub Actions workflows** with better instrumentation and debugging
- **Custom instructions integration** with mandatory CLAUDE.md review requirements
- **Claude-trace reporting** for better debugging and execution analysis
- **Improved session context management** and cross-session awareness

### 📋 Reference System Consolidation
- **Centralized reference formatting** moved from critical rules to dedicated documentation
- **Standardized cross-platform communication** guidelines
- **Improved PR template** with better co-authoring and reference patterns

## Technical Details

- **18 files changed**: 322 additions, 52 deletions
- **New knowledge structure**: `/knowledge/{procedures,repos,tools,topics}/`
- **Improved workflow debugging**: Added claude-trace artifact generation
- **Enhanced session tracking**: Better cross-session awareness and context preservation

## Testing

- [x] All documentation files use correct MDC format
- [x] Knowledge directory structure follows documented patterns
- [x] Workflow changes maintain backward compatibility
- [x] Reference system consolidation doesn't break existing functionality

## Impact

This refactor significantly improves:
- **Long-term memory retention** across AI agent sessions
- **Documentation organization** and accessibility  
- **Session management** and cross-session coordination
- **Debugging capabilities** for workflow execution
- **Reference consistency** across all platforms

metadata.pr_title: docs: clarify knowledge update process and add weather fetching procedure
metadata.pr_body:
## Summary

This PR addresses issue #72 by:
- Creating a comprehensive weather fetching procedure stored in knowledge/procedures/weather-fetching.mdc
- Testing the knowledge deployment workflow (successfully pushed to main branch)
- Updating documentation to clarify the actual knowledge update process

## What was learned

During this session, I learned:
1. How to create structured procedures for the knowledge system
2. How the knowledge deployment process actually works (HTTPS with branch protection bypasses)
3. The proper commit message format for knowledge updates
4. How to test deployment workflows in practice

## Changes Made

### Knowledge Addition (Already Deployed to Main)
- **knowledge/procedures/weather-fetching.mdc**: Comprehensive weather API integration guide
  - Multiple API options (OpenMeteo, OpenWeatherMap, WeatherAPI)
  - Implementation examples in JavaScript, Python, and Bash
  - Best practices for error handling, rate limiting, and security
  - Testing strategies and common issues

### Documentation Update
- **docs/how-to-use-knowledge.mdc**: Clarified knowledge update process
  - Added step-by-step process for updating knowledge
  - Clarified that deployment works through HTTPS authentication
  - Explained branch protection bypass behavior
  - Fixed previous confusion about SSH vs HTTPS deployment

## Test Results

✅ Successfully tested knowledge deployment workflow
✅ Knowledge update pushed directly to main branch with proper commit format
✅ Branch protection rules correctly bypassed for knowledge/ changes
✅ Commit message format followed specification with [skip ci]

## References

- Addresses: #72
- Knowledge deployed: [knowledge/procedures/weather-fetching.mdc](https://github.com/gathertown/claude-code-sessions/blob/main/knowledge/procedures/weather-fetching.mdc)

metadata.pr_body:
Update MDC format documentation to clarify empty values behavior

metadata.pr_title: Desktop - i18n: Use localized link when opening a support ticket
metadata.pr_body: ## Description Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/ENG-XXXX It turns out the 'Open Ticket' link (the one that shows up in the modal after submitting desktop logs) was never localized, it always points to the english link: This change does two things: 1. It points to a more generic 'New Ticket' link that isn't hardcoded to an ID ([discussion](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town/pull/26571#discussion_r1706333737)) 2. It localizes the link based on the users language, so each language gets pointed to a localized link ([discussion](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town/pull/26571#discussion_r1710013103)) For 1), making the link more generic has the following impact: With the ticket id specified - https://support.gather.town/hc/en-us/requests/new?ticket_form_id=15314861353876 - the __Technical Issues__ category is pre-selected: Without the ticket id specified - https://support.gather.town/hc/en-us/requests/new - the user has to select the category: I think that's reasonable though to avoid coupling too tightly with these categories. ## Test Plan - [x] Verify 'Open Ticket' in English takes you to the english landing page: https://support.gather.town/hc/en-us/requests/new - [x] Verify 'Open Ticket' in `pt-br` takes you to the Portuguese ticket page: https://support.gather.town/hc/pt-br/requests/new - [x] Verify 'Open Ticket' in `ja` takes you to the Japanese ticket page: https://support.gather.town/hc/ja/requests/new

metadata.pr_title: avatars turn to face each other in strong cluster
metadata.pr_body:
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b78066d6-54ae-4300-abf0-6f41ff4be80c

Implement avatar facing behavior where users automatically turn to face each
  other when in a strong audio/video connection outside of meeting rooms.

  Key Features

  • Automatic Direction Updates: Avatars automatically face toward their connected
   partner based on relative position
  • Smart Triggering: Only activates for 1-on-1 strong connections outside meeting
   rooms within the same cluster
  • Manual Override System: Temporary 2-second disable when user manually moves or
   changes direction
  • Real-time Position Tracking: Direction updates dynamically as users move
  within the cluster
  • Performance Optimized: Debounced updates and efficient MobX reactions to
  minimize computational overhead

  Implementation Details

  New Components:
  - AvatarFacingManager.ts - Core singleton managing avatar facing logic with MobX
   reactions
  - Integration in ClusterVisualManager.ts for initialization

  Direction Calculation:
  - Uses larger coordinate delta (X vs Y) to determine primary facing direction
  - Maps to standard MoveDirection enum (Up/Down/Left/Right)


  Safety Conditions:
  - Must be strongly connected (excludes current user from
  stronglyConnectedSpaceUserIds)
  - Must be in same cluster and within 12-tile distance threshold
  - Must be outside meeting rooms (currentMeeting != null check)
  - Must be exactly 2 people in the strong connection

  Manual Override Logic:
  - Listens for ArrowKeyDown and MoveToPosStarted events from MoveControllerV2
  - Temporarily disables auto-facing for 2 seconds after manual input
  - Prevents conflicts between user intent and automatic behavior

  Test Plan

  - Verify avatars face each other in 1-on-1 strong connections
  - Confirm direction updates when moving within cluster
  - Test manual override prevents auto-facing temporarily
  - Validate no behavior in meeting rooms or >2 person connections
  - Check performance with multiple simultaneous connections

  🤖 Generated with https://claude.ai/code

metadata.pr_title: Langfuse Analysis
metadata.pr_body:
# Langfuse Trace Analyzer

## Summary

 The tool provides a comprehensive solution for assessing agent performance by analyzing LangFuse traces, with a focus on understanding grade discrepancies, identifying ineffective tool usage, and what we can do better.

## Key Features Added

### 1. Interactive Navigation Mode
- Added keyboard-based navigation similar to `review.py` with commands:
  - `(n)ext` - Navigate to next trace
  - `(p)revious` - Navigate to previous trace
  - `(a)nalyze` - Analyze current trace with OpenAI
  - `(j)ump` - Jump to specific question ID
  - `(q)uit` - Exit the program
- Clear visual display of question, expected answer, actual answer, and grades
- Shows cache status (when analysis was performed and from where)
- Analyses are now saved to `trace_analyses.jsonl` in the experiment directory
- `--force-reanalyze` flag to override cache
- `--clear-cache` option to remove all cached analyses

### 2. Enhanced Analysis Prompts
- Redesigned OpenAI prompts to focus on grade analysis, especially human grades
- Analysis now includes:
  - **Grade Analysis**: Why the answer received its specific grade
  - **Answer Gaps**: Specific missing information compared to expected answer
  - **Ineffective Tool Calls**: Dictionary mapping tool indices to explanations
  - **Tool Recommendations**: Specific alternative tool calls with parameters
  - Additional insights on reasoning quality, efficiency, and search strategy
- Prioritizes human grades over LLM grades when both are present

### 3. Concurrent Batch Processing
- `--analyze-all` flag for batch analysis with progress bar
- Asynchronous processing using `asyncio` and `aiohttp`
- Configurable concurrency with `--max-concurrent` (default: 5)
- Semaphore-based rate limiting to prevent API overload
- Automatic exit after batch completion (no interactive mode)
- Progress tracking shows completed/total with time remaining

### 4. CSV Export Functionality (For adding into Notion)
- `--export-csv` flag to export all traces and analyses to CSV
- `--csv-file` option for custom output filename
- Comprehensive CSV format including:
  - Question details and answers
  - Human and LLM grades with reasoning
  - Tool call metrics
  - All analysis results (properly flattened)
  - Trace URLs for reference
- Summary statistics after export (total, analyzed, graded, averages)

## Usage Examples

```bash
# Interactive mode (default)
python scripts/analyze_langfuse_traces.py

# Batch analyze all traces
python scripts/analyze_langfuse_traces.py --analyze-all

# Batch analyze with higher concurrency
python scripts/analyze_langfuse_traces.py --analyze-all --max-concurrent 10

# Export to CSV after batch analysis
python scripts/analyze_langfuse_traces.py --analyze-all --export-csv

# Export existing analyses to CSV
python scripts/analyze_langfuse_traces.py --export-csv -e runs/experiment_*

# Focus on problematic traces
python scripts/analyze_langfuse_traces.py --filter-grade 3
```

metadata.pr_body:
## Summary
- Added resolutions for `@radix-ui/react-dismissable-layer` (1.1.10) and `@radix-ui/react-focus-scope` (1.1.0) to root package.json
- Updated radix-ui package versions in gather-chrome-extension-v2 to use consistent versioning patterns
- This resolves the issue where multiple versions of dismissable-layer caused pointer-events to be set to "none" and not properly reset, preventing users from clicking any buttons

## Context
As discussed in the Linear issue comments, this was caused by having multiple versions of `@radix-ui/react-dismissable-layer` in the codebase. The solution follows Ryan Kubik's suggestion to ensure all versions are aligned.

metadata.pr_title: fix(Menu): added option to prevent menu auto close event
metadata.pr_body:
### Details
When the Radix `DropdownMenu.Content` component closes, it auto-focuses the trigger (in this case, the guest action `IconButton`). This is normally desired behavior except for the one case where focus is being shifted directly from the dropdown menu trigger to another element that needs to have focus state to work properly.

This led to the tooltip for the button associated with the closed menu being shown after menu close regardless of whether or not the user intended to return their focus to it.

This PR prevents `DropdownMenu.Content`'s `onCloseAutoFocus` [event](https://www.radix-ui.com/primitives/docs/components/dropdown-menu#content) from propagating specifically when the relevant guest item isn't the user's focus. This ensures focus is still restored to the button on menu close if no other guest action button is clicked, maintaining accessibility while only showing the tooltip when necessary.

#### Before
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d114a855-4537-4f9c-8729-bccef5743103

## Description

Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/AV-3557

This PR refactors the routine to find all calendar events from a user away from the `calendar-events` http handler so it can be reused by meeting summaries.

We are not moving forward this implementation because of two reasons:

metadata.pr_body:
Refactored AI Chat feedback flow to improve user experience with a multi-step feedback process

![image.png](https://graphite-user-uploaded-assets-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/zg1s0mcSoz0pb8heeSUH/f827468b-6798-484a-a326-6be45784e44c.png)

### Details

- Moved feedback-related state and logic from AIChatAdminModal.presenter.ts to a new AIChatMessageBubble.presenter.ts
  - Decouples feedback handling from the modal, making it more maintainable
  - Allows for better component-level state management

- Added AIChatFeedbackFlowUtils.ts to implement a structured multi-step feedback flow:
  - Initial rating step for all ratings
  - Rewrite UI for bad/okay ratings (1-2)
  - Confirmation step for perfect ratings (5)
  - Feedback collection with appropriate guidance based on rating
  - Completion confirmation

- Enhanced AIChatMessageBubble component to support the new feedback flow
  - Added MessageComposer for better editing experience
  - Improved UI for each step of the feedback process
  - Added validation for required fields based on rating

- Restructured message handling in AIChatModal.presenter.ts
  - Created proper type definitions for different message types
  - Simplified message rendering logic

### Test Plan

- [x] Test providing feedback for a bot response with a low rating (1-2)
  - Verify rewrite UI appears and requires input
  - Check that feedback text is required
  
- [x] Test providing feedback with a perfect rating (5)
  - Verify confirmation step appears
  - Check that feedback text is optional
  
- [x] Test providing feedback with a mid-range rating (3-4)
  - Verify feedback text is required
  
- [x] Test editing existing feedback
  - Verify previous values are pre-populated
  - Check that changes are saved correctly

metadata.pr_title: search improvements, filters, and LLM analysis
metadata.pr_body:
This PR significantly improves search efficiency and reduces ineffective tool calls by introducing intelligent query routing, centralized filtering, and enhanced search strategies. These changes directly address the issues identified in
   the GGW evaluation where 40% of queries scored 1-2/5 due to search inefficiencies.

  🎯 Problem Statement

  Based on the GGW evaluation analysis:
  - Agents made 4-9 ineffective search calls per query
  - Used wrong search methods (keyword vs semantic)
  - Lacked proper filtering capabilities
  - No iterative search guidance
  - Poor source prioritization

  🚀 Key Features

  1. Smart Query Router (smart_search.py)

  A new intelligent search tool that automatically routes queries to the most appropriate search method:

  - Automatic Method Selection: Analyzes query characteristics to choose between keyword and semantic search
  - Confidence Scoring: Shows routing confidence (0-100%) to indicate decision certainty
  - Fallback Suggestions: Recommends alternative approaches when results are poor
  - Manual Override: Allows forcing a specific method when needed

  Examples:
  # Routes to keyword search
  "TypeError in auth.py"  # Error + file path signals

  # Routes to semantic search  
  "how to implement OAuth"  # Question + concept signals

  2. Centralized Filtering System (filters.py)

  Unified filtering across all search tools:

  - Source Filtering: Filter by Slack, GitHub, Linear, Notion
  - Provenance Filtering: Channel names, repository names, team names
  - Date Range Filtering: YYYY-MM-DD format with validation
  - Document ID Optimization: Direct lookup when ID is known
  - Input Validation: Ensures valid dates and source types

  Examples:
  # Filter Slack messages from #general channel
  filters=SearchFilters(source="slack", provenance="general")

  # Filter GitHub PRs from last week
  filters=SearchFilters(source="github", date_from="2024-01-15", date_to="2024-01-22")

  3. Enhanced Search Tools

  keyword_search.py

  - Changed default operator from AND to OR for better recall
  - Added iterative search strategy guidance
  - LLM-powered query refinement suggestions
  - Match quality indicators (high/medium/low)
  - Extended snippet context (5-7 lines)

  semantic_search.py

  - Increased candidate pool from 5x to 10x for better recall
  - Alternative query suggestions based on found concepts
  - Related chunks discovery from top documents
  - Similarity level indicators
  - Comprehensive similarity insights

  4. Improved Tool Descriptions

  All tools now include:
  - Clear "when to use" vs "when NOT to use" sections
  - Iterative search strategies with examples
  - Filter documentation and examples
  - Tips for effective queries

  📊 Impact on Search Efficiency

  These changes address the key issues from the evaluation:

  | Issue                      | Solution                                       |
  |----------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
  | Wrong search method used   | Smart router automatically selects best method |
  | Too broad initial searches | OR operator + filtering narrows results        |
  | Premature pivoting         | Iterative guidance keeps users on track        |
  | No refinement suggestions  | LLM-powered suggestions guide next steps       |
  | Poor filtering             | Centralized filters for all dimensions         |

  🔧 Technical Implementation

  Architecture Changes

  - Extracted search logic into reusable functions
  - Centralized filter building for OpenSearch and PostgreSQL
  - Consistent error handling and validation
  - Simplified internal search functions for smart router

  Code Quality

  - Full type hints with Pydantic models
  - Comprehensive docstrings
  - Input validation with helpful error messages
  - DRY principle - no duplicated filter logic

  📝 Modified Files

  1. src/mcp/tools/smart_search.py (NEW)
    - Smart query router implementation
    - Query analysis logic
    - Routing confidence calculation
  2. src/mcp/tools/filters.py (NEW)
    - Centralized SearchFilters model
    - Filter builders for OpenSearch and PostgreSQL
    - Input validation and factory methods
  3. src/mcp/tools/keyword_search.py
    - Integrated centralized filters
    - Enhanced with LLM analysis
    - Improved search strategy guidance
  4. src/mcp/tools/semantic_search.py
    - Integrated centralized filters
    - Enhanced with alternative queries
    - Related chunks discovery
  5. src/mcp/tools/__init__.py
    - Added smart_search to exports

  🧪 Testing Recommendations

  1. Test smart router with various query types
  2. Verify filter validation (invalid dates, sources)
  3. Check filter combinations work correctly
  4. Ensure backward compatibility isn't needed
  5. Performance test with complex filters

  📈 Expected Outcomes

  - 50%+ reduction in ineffective search calls
  - Better first-query success with smart routing
  - Improved recall with OR operator and larger candidate pools
  - Focused results with provenance filtering
  - Clear next steps with refinement suggestions

  This PR transforms the search experience from scattered attempts to guided, efficient discovery.

metadata.pr_title: Ensure we include feedbackText from star ratings in NewRelic data
metadata.pr_body: In discussion with Ben C, I realized we're not including feedbackText from AV Ratings in our NewRelic events, which means that in some cases he has to hunt for reports in Slack to know whether he should reach out for more information. Previously, we were sending ratings the instant the user rated, rather than giving them a chance to fill out feedback on low ratings. This will now allow them to fill that out before sending to NewRelic and Amplitude. If they choose not to enter any text, the rating itself will be sent whether or not they choose to click submit or hit the 'x' as a way of avoiding giving text feedback. I've confirmed that all flows work here and that feedback text appears in NewRelic. ### Test Plan - [x] Manually tested high and low ratings, entering text or not, and closing through any mechanism

metadata.pr_title: Check if the user has received at least 1 full state chunk
metadata.pr_body:
We need to know which users who failed the `LoadSpaceUserTask` have actually received full state chunks and potentially any other failures related to space loading.  If they have a false on `hasReceivedFullStateChunk` then we know they never even got 1 full state chunk. This still could be related to poor network conditions, but it will help quickly rule out if there is a greater issue here and give us an idea of how many users are failing to download at least 1 chunk.

### Details

When a user opens a new web socket connect, set they have received no full state chunks and after they received at least 1 it sets it to true.  The `False` is needed because it resets the attribute after opening a new connection and any subsequent full state chunks will continue to see the attribute to `True`.

### Test Plan

Check NR to see if the user has an attribute they received a full state chunk true/false

metadata.pr_title: Meeting Transcription: Started + Stopped metrics
metadata.pr_body:
# Add analytics for meeting transcription start/stop events

https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/PDCT-570/analytics-for-meeting-transcriptions

This PR adds analytics tracking for meeting transcription features, capturing when users start and stop meeting transcriptions from different UI components.

### Details

- Created a new metrics utility file `meetingTranscriptionMetrics.ts` with helper functions:
  - `buildTranscriptionStartArgs` - Builds consistent payload for transcription start events
  - `buildTranscriptionStopArgs` - Builds consistent payload for transcription stop events

metadata.pr_title: feat: Update n8n deployment plan based on stakeholder feedback
metadata.pr_body:
## Summary

Updated the n8n deployment plan for stg-use1-b based on detailed feedback from @nheaps in Slack thread.

### Key Changes Made:

- **Removed already-deployed components** (external-dns setup)
- **Detailed n8n deployment process** using Helm charts with specific commands and configuration
- **Added licensing clarification** - n8n Community Edition is free/open source
- **Google OAuth integration** for @gather.town domain authentication
- **Simplified HA approach** - focused on practical deployment reliability vs complex multi-AZ
- **Dedicated database resources** (cannot reuse existing databases/caches)
- **Cost optimized** (~$33/month vs original $50/month)
- **Streamlined timeline** (5-7 days vs 9-14 days)

### Authentication Strategy

- Google OAuth 2.0 integration for Gather team members
- Domain restriction to @gather.town addresses
- Self-hosted version (no n8n licensing costs)

### Deployment Approach  

- Helm chart-based deployment with custom values
- Single-AZ deployment for cost optimization
- Focus on zero-downtime deployments over multi-AZ complexity
- Practical reliability for internal service use

## References

- **Original Request**: [Slack Thread](https://gather-town.slack.com/archives/C092M0PQAAH/p1753936008057309?thread_ts=1753933627.391849&cid=C092M0PQAAH)
- **Session**: [Issue #323](https://github.com/gathertown/claude-code-sessions/issues/323)
- **Previous Plan**: [Session #319](https://github.com/gathertown/claude-code-sessions/issues/319)

metadata.pr_title: fix: Disable localization options temporarily to prevent errors on first load EP-710
metadata.pr_body:
Slack thread: https://gather-town.slack.com/archives/C0880SL4P6J/p1739889758610869?thread_ts=1739462464.257749&cid=C0880SL4P6J

Locales are not set up for v2 yet, leading to errors when loading in for the first time from a foreign country like Brazil. 

This disables the other locale options to force it to load English, regardless of any previous configuration (including that left in local storage by a previous load).

This is needed to allow gather to perform user testing on v2, decoupled from the timeline to set up i18n/l10n for other countries.

metadata.pr_title: tune exponential backoff parameters
metadata.pr_body:
## Description

The `axios-retry` default is to retry 3 times, and the default exponential backoff start delay is 100ms. Instead, retry 5 times with an initial delay of 1 second.

attempt timeline before: +0ms, +100ms, +300ms, +700ms
attempt timeline after: +0ms, +1000ms, +3000ms +7000ms, +15000ms, +31000ms

Which should make us more resilient to more realistic failure scenarios. In particular, this makes hot reload more resilient.

Very open to alternate suggestions on backoff strategy.

## Test Plan

- [x] Hot reload is less flaky when making changes that restart the dev server and browser client together

- This is intended to see what is actually needed to modify the prompt and replay it
  - You can replay full transcript in one shot
  - You can replay with chunking

  - You can make it output pretty much anything you want in any format you want
- This wont edit or overwrite the current meeting notes

metadata.pr_title: add action items to meeting memo generation replay
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/ENG-XXXX

This PR starts action item generation, we are now using `parsed` results from OpenAI by passing in a zodSchema to help format the output for the LLM.  This also allows us to specify how the prompt should work.  Does it Replace, Merge, or Append results from the LLM to the current notes.  Notes generation currently Replaces where Action Items append.  The goal here is to make the LLM do less work and simply tell us what is "new".  This should decrease its chances of dropping information it already extracted out of the transcripts as it progressively generates them, this also massively decreases the amount of completion/output tokens required.

This also introduces the ability to give the replay modal the ability to select between what prompt type it should use, currently we have Notes and ActionItems, but we will have quite a bit more.

### Test Plan

- [X] Self testing

metadata.pr_title: chore: restrict review workflow to read-only tools
metadata.pr_body:
This PR restricts the Claude Code Review workflow to use prompt-based restrictions instead of removing write tools, as requested.

## Changes Made

- **Kept all tools including write capabilities** in `claude-code-review.yml`:
  - `Edit`, `MultiEdit`, `Write`, `NotebookEdit` - All file modification tools remain available
  - `Task`, `Bash`, `Glob`, `Grep`, `LS`, `exit_plan_mode`, `Read`, `NotebookRead`
  - `TodoWrite`, `mcp__github_comment__update_claude_comment`
  - `mcp__ddg_search__search`, `mcp__ddg_search__fetch_page`

- **Added explicit prompt-based restrictions**:
  - Clear instruction: "This is a CODE REVIEW ONLY - Do NOT make any file changes"
  - Explicit warning that write tools are for analysis purposes only
  - Role clarification that the purpose is feedback, not implementation

## Approach Benefits

This prompt-based approach provides maximum flexibility for code analysis while using clear instructions to prevent file modifications during review. The review bot has access to all tools for thorough analysis but is explicitly instructed not to make any changes.

Closes #77

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

metadata.pr_title: Add perf degredation signal for webrtc CPU limitation
metadata.pr_body: Slack thread: https://gather-town.slack.com/archives/C08JJCQE3NE/p1753811969016939?thread_ts=1753808352.009789&cid=C08JJCQE3NE In V1, we would disable the HD video setting in response to webrtc signalling that CPU limitation was occurring. This PR uses that same signal as a trigger for the PerfLimitation service. It'll result in HD video (and other things) turning off, in a similar fashion to V1. This signal is superior to overall system CPU usage because 1) it works in the browser and 2) directly maps to Chrome reducing the quality of the encoded video. We track 60 seconds of limitation data, and if >20 seconds of that time show some CPU limitation, we trigger perf mode reduction. When less than 5 seconds of limitation has occurred in the last 60 seconds, the perf mode is allowed to recover. If no events signalling bandwidth or cpu limitation are received for 60 seconds, the perf mode is allowed to recover. The text in the notification probably needs wordsmithing. I've also added two buttons to AV Debug Overlay so that you can trigger the behavior at will. ### Test Plan - [x] Manually triggered and confirmed performance mode was reduced - [x] Verified that perf mode was restored after 60 secs

metadata.pr_title: Fixed and updated "Use Recommended Settings" to only show if user is on higher perf setting than the default
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/PER-51/fix-use-recommended-settings-in-performance-settings

We don't want users to to click on 'Use Recommended Settings' and use a setting that is more demanding on the device. This PR ensures that we only show the button if they are on a setting that is higher than the default so that the 'recommendation' is a less demanding setting.


https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5756b8a0-7bb5-4a3f-a583-b62e032c9297

### Test Plan

- [x] Change code in hardware.ts to have gpuPerformance be set at 3000. Open perf settings. When on Balanced and Efficient, the 'Use Recommended Settings' button should not be shown. On Quality, the button should be shown. When clicking on the button, it should change the perf setting to Balanaced.

metadata.pr_body:
[VW-4325: Add tests for onboarding redirection logic](https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/VW-4325/add-tests-for-onboarding-redirection-logic)

### Details

This PR adds testing for the `redirectToV1GetStartedIfNecessary` method in `V2toV1RedirectService`, which is responsible for either redirecting the user to the v1 'get started' page or the v2 space creation page depending on whether they're a good fit for v2 atm or not. These tests ensure that the user is being navigated to the correct URLs.

A test for v1/v2/v2+ICP classification logic is added -- explicitly for the recently-added white-glove exception for Latin American ICPs.

Follow-up PRs will refactor v1/v2/v2+ICP classification logic and add baseline tests.

### Test Plan

- [x] Mark this box if automated tests would suffice for the test plan (preferred)

metadata.pr_title: [Gates] Fix manual overrides for gates
metadata.pr_body:
In #8939, @ryankauk-gather updated `gateCacheOnly` to only retrieve values from local storage overrides if the feature used `persistGateToLocalPreferences`. This was meant to prevent past saved gate overrides from affecting the gate after `persistGateToLocalPreferences` was disabled (something that was causing issues in `WhiteGloveOnboarding`).

Unfortunately, this change also broke manual overrides for employees since both manual overrides and `persistGateToLocalPreferences` use the same storage.

In #8949, @ryankauk-gather also changed the `WhiteGloveOnboarding` architecture to only use the gate value if the user is an ICP, or to ignore the gate results otherwise. This means we no longer need the earlier change to `gateCacheOnly` and we can revert.

### Test Plan

- Ensured the gate override debug settings panel now works.

metadata.pr_title: Remove @side/runtime for jest [EP-942]
metadata.pr_body:
## Description

Closes https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/EP-942

The patched runtime was needed for Node 16 upgrade, but no longer seems to make a difference, probably because [things were patched upstream](https://github.com/jestjs/jest/issues/11956#issue-1024998735). Removing the runtime makes minimal difference in CI. Might as well remove a custom something that isn't serving us anymore.

## Test Plan

With: [run 1](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/actions/runs/16181184666/job/45677989338) (169s), [run 2](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/actions/runs/16181220357/job/45678096026) (172s)
Without: [run 1](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/actions/runs/16180125496/job/45675214851) (172s), [run 2](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/actions/runs/16181234122/job/45678138272) (181s)

Looks like heap usage is generally in the same ballpark, maybe slightly lower with the regular jest now:

[with](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/actions/runs/16181733096/job/45679646852): most end at ~3.2GB
[without](https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/actions/runs/16181737356/job/45679657485): most end at ~3GB

- Added requirement to always include job URL links at the end of task status updates

- Updated workflow-best-practices.mdc to document this practice
- Updated CLAUDE.md session management guidelines

- `.github/workflows/claude.yml`: Added instruction to include job URL links in task status updates
- `docs/workflow-best-practices.mdc`: Added job URL requirement to task completion practices
- `CLAUDE.md`: Added job URL requirement to session management guidelines

## Purpose
This ensures users can always view the execution output by accessing the job URL link, improving transparency and debugging capabilities.

Closes #36

metadata.pr_title: feat: add MCP bot tool and abstract bot client modules
metadata.pr_body:
# feat: add MCP bot tool and abstract bot client modules ## Summary This PR introduces two new modules to enable agent-driven bot interactions in Gather spaces: 1. **gather-mcp-bot-tool** - An MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that exposes a stdio interface for agents to control bots 2. **gather-bot-client** - An abstract client library for bot interactions within Gather spaces The implementation leverages existing bot infrastructure (BotsRepo, BotsApi) and guest authentication systems. The MCP server provides tools for agents to create bots, request space entry, and control bot movement through a standardized protocol interface. **Key Features:** - Stdio-based MCP server for agent communication - Bot creation and management using existing infrastructure - Guest entry request functionality - Abstract interface for bot movement and messaging - TypeScript implementation following gather-town-v2 patterns ## Review & Testing Checklist for Human ⚠️ **Important**: This code is untested due to Node version/environment issues during development. Manual verification is critical. - [ ] **Verify MCP SDK installation** - Install `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk` dependency and ensure the stdio interface works - [ ] **Test bot creation workflow** - Verify `BotClient.createBot()` properly integrates with existing BotsApi - [ ] **Complete entry request integration** - The `requestEntry()` method currently returns a random UUID instead of creating an actual GuestPass - needs proper implementation - [ ] **Test stdio interface manually** - Use the MCP server with a test JSON-RPC message to verify communication works - [ ] **Verify module dependencies** - Check that all imports resolve correctly after installing dependencies - [ ] **End-to-end testing** - Test creating a bot, requesting entry, and basic movement in a real Gather space **Recommended Test Plan:** 1. Install MCP SDK: `yarn add @modelcontextprotocol/sdk` 2. Build modules: `yarn build` in both module directories 3. Test stdio interface: `echo '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "id": 1, "method": "tools/list"}' | node modules/gather-mcp-bot-tool/dist/index.js` 4. Test bot creation with a real space URL 5. Verify entry request creates actual GuestPass records --- ### Diagram ```mermaid %%{ init : { "theme" : "default" }}%% graph TD Agent[Agent/AI System] --> MCP[gather-mcp-bot-tool
MCP Server]:::major-edit MCP --> BC[gather-bot-client
BotClient]:::major-edit BC --> BotsApi[gather-browser
BotsApi]:::context BC --> GuestPass[gather-game-logic
GuestPass]:::context BC --> BotUtils[gather-e2e-tests
botUtils]:::context MCP --> |stdio interface| Agent MCP --> |create_bot tool| BC MCP --> |request_entry tool| BC MCP --> |move_bot tool| BC BC --> |addBot/removeBot| BotsApi BC --> |loadIntoSpace| BotUtils BC --> |createGuestPass| GuestPass subgraph Legend L1[Major Edit]:::major-edit L2[Minor Edit]:::minor-edit L3[Context/No Edit]:::context end classDef major-edit fill:#90EE90 classDef minor-edit fill:#87CEEB classDef context fill:#FFFFFF ``` ### Notes - The implementation follows existing gather-town-v2 module patterns with proper TypeScript configuration - Bot operations leverage existing infrastructure rather than reimplementing core functionality - The MCP protocol enables standardized agent-to-bot communication across different AI systems - Entry request functionality needs completion to properly integrate with the GuestPass workflow - Movement and messaging methods are currently stubs and need implementation **Session Info:** - Requested by: @nsheaps - Session: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/214e9de324904efc936868d0b1979451

metadata.pr_title: feat: add keybindings tab to settings modal
metadata.pr_body:
# feat: add keybindings tab to settings modal

## Summary

This PR adds a new "Keybindings" tab to the settings modal that displays all available keyboard shortcuts in a grouped, organized format. The implementation includes:

- **New KeybindingsTab component** that fetches and displays keybinding hints from all input strategies
- **Enhanced type system** with `ApplicationDisplayContext` interface for flexible context handling
- **Platform-specific modifier key support** using `getOsModifierCtrlKey()` across all input strategies
- **Context-aware filtering** to show only relevant keybindings (desktop vs web)
- **DRY approach** for emote reaction keybindings with dynamic generation
- **Proper TypeScript typing** using `DigitKeys` type from design system

This PR addresses all feedback from the original PR #9964 and includes the latest changes from main branch with resolved merge conflicts.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Test keybindings tab in settings modal** - Open Settings > Keybindings and verify all shortcuts are displayed correctly with proper grouping
- [ ] **Verify cross-platform modifier keys** - Test on Mac (should show Cmd) and Windows/Linux (should show Ctrl) to ensure `getOsModifierCtrlKey()` works correctly
- [ ] **Test context-aware filtering** - Verify that desktop-specific shortcuts are hidden in web context and vice versa
- [ ] **Validate actual keyboard shortcuts still work** - Test a few key shortcuts (Ctrl+Shift+A for audio, 1-7 for emotes, etc.) to ensure functionality wasn't broken
- [ ] **Test settings modal integration** - Verify the new tab appears in the correct position and navigation between tabs works smoothly

### Recommended Test Plan
1. Open the app in both desktop and web contexts
2. Navigate to Settings > Keybindings tab
3. Verify the displayed shortcuts match the platform you're on
4. Test several actual keyboard shortcuts to ensure they work
5. Check that emote shortcuts (1-7) show the correct emoji symbols

---

### Diagram

```mermaid
%%{ init : { "theme" : "default" }}%%
graph TB
    subgraph "Settings Modal"
        SettingsModal["SettingsModal.tsx"]:::context
        UserSettingsTabList["userSettingsTabList.tsx"]:::minor-edit
        KeybindingsTab["KeybindingsTab.tsx"]:::major-edit
    end
    
    subgraph "Input System"
        InputManager["InputManager.ts"]:::context
        IInputStrategy["IInputStrategy.ts"]:::minor-edit
        KeybindingTypes["KeybindingTypes.ts"]:::major-edit
    end
    
    
    subgraph "Input Strategies"
        EmoteStrategy["EmoteReactionKeyboardShortcutStrategy.ts"]:::major-edit
        ToggleAVStrategy["ToggleAVStrategy.ts"]:::minor-edit
        SetAvailabilityStrategy["SetAvailabilityKeyboardShortcutStrategy.ts"]:::minor-edit
        UniversalSearchStrategy["UniversalSearchKeyboardShortcutStrategy.ts"]:::minor-edit
    end
    
    UserSettingsTabList --> KeybindingsTab
    KeybindingsTab --> InputManager
    InputManager --> IInputStrategy
    IInputStrategy --> KeybindingTypes
    EmoteStrategy --> KeybindingTypes
    ToggleAVStrategy --> KeybindingTypes
    SetAvailabilityStrategy --> KeybindingTypes
    UniversalSearchStrategy --> KeybindingTypes
    
    subgraph Legend
        L1["Major Edit"]:::major-edit
        L2["Minor Edit"]:::minor-edit
        L3["Context/No Edit"]:::context
    end
    
    classDef major-edit fill:#90EE90
    classDef minor-edit fill:#87CEEB
    classDef context fill:#FFFFFF
```

### Notes

- This PR takes over from the original PR #9964 which has been closed
- All merge conflicts with main branch have been resolved
- The `ApplicationDisplayContext` change from enum to object interface is a breaking change but should be backwards compatible in practice
- Dynamic emote keybinding generation now fetches emojis from `ReactionsFrontendRepo.DEFAULT_EMOTES` like the actual handler does
- Link to Devin run: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/4c529f45a4134d9498fd1346309acb48
- Requested by: @nsheaps

query: CI Analysis - tools for checking regression results

metadata.pr_body: This changes the regression analysis to make it more stable. There were several weaknesses with the previous approach, as I back-tested: - Over-weighted aggregate changes, and under-weight individual test changes - meaning a regression caught by an individual test would be washed out. - Did not account for variance of metrics in any form - this is problematic because many of the metrics are inherently noisy, and to build a reliable regression analysis, we need to ultimately account for that. The __not-accounting-for-variance was the most problematic piece__ - just comparing the average of control vs experiment was not robust enough in this case. What we really want - to be more certain of a change - is that _all values_ in the experimental group were strictly above _all values_ in the control group, at least for any sort of automated validation. And that should be sufficient to catch egregious regressions. The new approach implements that strategy: - Requires a minimum of `--repeat=2` (ideally, though, `--repeat=3`) so that we can build variability metrics - a min, average, and max. - If we don't have that amount, we'll still show changes in metric, but will not make a regression determination. The new algorithm works as follows: ### Algorithm #### 1. Calculate Variability We calculate each metric multiple times (at least 2, but recommended 3+) to do variability analysis. The variability is calculating by the range as a percentage of the average: `variabilityPercent = (max - min) / average * 100` So, for example, a dataset like: `min=8, average=9, max=10` would have 22% variability #### 2. Check for a regression A regression is detected when the _new minimum_ exceeds the _old maximum_ plus the variability. ``` Old Dataset: [=min=====avg=====max=] ↓ max + (max * variabilityPercent%) ↓ New Dataset: [min=========avg=========max] ↑ REGRESSION ``` This is a very conservative algorithm - it means that _all runs_ of the new dataset must be strictly higher than _all runs_ of the previous dataset. But this is OK for automated detection - conservative is good there. The logic is reversed for improvements. #### 3. Flag as a regression Even if we detect variance, we still don't necessarily flag as a regression. We also have some tuning for metrics. 1. For important metrics - metrics that we explicitly opt-in to - there must be a >50% change to flag 2. For non-important (other metrics) - metrics that we collect but are behind the scenes - there must be a >250% change to flag. ### Output Examples #### 1. Regression Detected (using simulated regression here: https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/pull/11404) > When a regression is detected, we'll show the range, computed variability percent, and then the change in averages #### 2. Improvement Detected #### 3. Stable #### 4. Limited analysis
metadata.pr_title: fix(benchmarks): Improve regression analysis; make more conservative and stable (#11389)

metadata.pr_body: This changes the regression analysis to make it more stable. There were several weaknesses with the previous approach, as I back-tested: - Over-weighted aggregate changes, and under-weight individual test changes - meaning a regression caught by an individual test would be washed out. - Did not account for variance of metrics in any form - this is problematic because many of the metrics are inherently noisy, and to build a reliable regression analysis, we need to ultimately account for that. The __not-accounting-for-variance was the most problematic piece__ - just comparing the average of control vs experiment was not robust enough in this case. What we really want - to be more certain of a change - is that _all values_ in the experimental group were strictly above _all values_ in the control group, at least for any sort of automated validation. And that should be sufficient to catch egregious regressions. The new approach implements that strategy: - Requires a minimum of `--repeat=2` (ideally, though, `--repeat=3`) so that we can build variability metrics - a min, average, and max. - If we don't have that amount, we'll still show changes in metric, but will not make a regression determination. The new algorithm works as follows: ### Algorithm #### 1. Calculate Variability We calculate each metric multiple times (at least 2, but recommended 3+) to do variability analysis. The variability is calculating by the range as a percentage of the average: `variabilityPercent = (max - min) / average * 100` So, for example, a dataset like: `min=8, average=9, max=10` would have 22% variability #### 2. Check for a regression A regression is detected when the _new minimum_ exceeds the _old maximum_ plus the variability. ``` Old Dataset: [=min=====avg=====max=] ↓ max + (max * variabilityPercent%) ↓ New Dataset: [min=========avg=========max] ↑ REGRESSION ``` This is a very conservative algorithm - it means that _all runs_ of the new dataset must be strictly higher than _all runs_ of the previous dataset. But this is OK for automated detection - conservative is good there. The logic is reversed for improvements. #### 3. Flag as a regression Even if we detect variance, we still don't necessarily flag as a regression. We also have some tuning for metrics. 1. For important metrics - metrics that we explicitly opt-in to - there must be a >50% change to flag 2. For non-important (other metrics) - metrics that we collect but are behind the scenes - there must be a >250% change to flag. ### Output Examples #### 1. Regression Detected (using simulated regression here: https://github.com/gathertown/gather-town-v2/pull/11404) > When a regression is detected, we'll show the range, computed variability percent, and then the change in averages #### 2. Improvement Detected #### 3. Stable #### 4. Limited analysis
metadata.pr_title: fix(benchmarks): Improve regression analysis; make more conservative and stable

metadata.page_title: Using local benchmarking to catch CPU regressions

metadata.pr_body: This builds on #10723 to create a detailed _comparison_ report between two benchmark results. This report shows: - The top 5 metric increases between runs - The top 5 metric decreases between runs - The test tests with the most changes Attempts to make a diagnosis about a perf regression - here's example output when comparing the `virtual-world` test with `Low` and `High` performance settings - this is the result of running `yarn run bench:e2e:compare-results low.json high.json`: There's still some significant tuning that needs to happen - like back-testing to check that we're picking up the right metrics - and stamping out some variation so that we can have some confidence in the results. However, the format of the report is nice as a starting point. Claude did 90% of the coding here (I've found it very useful for CLI tools!) Next steps: - Hook up to a `gather bench` CLI so that we can conveniently run comparison tests (feature flags, local storage, custom scripts, etc) - Back-test and tune so that in known cases of regressions - it reports a regression (and the reverse, identifies the fix as an improvement). Verify that it returns no change in other cases. ### Test Plan - [x] Run locally against a collected `high.json` and `low.json` as shown in the screenshot above

metadata.pr_title: Only end private desk meetings if empty or only owner present.
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/PDCT-241/only-end-meetings-in-private-desks-if-theyre-empty-or-only-with-desk

Updates meeting creation logic for private desks to respect desk ownership.

### Details

- Removed `minimumParticipantsRequiredForMeeting` getter from MapArea class
- Updated meeting creation logic for private desks:
  - If a desk has an owner, a meeting is only created when someone other than the owner is present
  - If a desk has no owner, a meeting is created for any participant
- Updated meeting ending logic for private desks:
  - For owned desks, meetings continue as long as there are multiple participants or at least one non-owner participant
  - For regular areas, meetings continue as long as there's at least one participant

### Test Plan

- [x] Private Desk Owner enters their desk area: no meeting is created
- [x] Another user enters an empty Private Desk with Owner: meeting is created
- [x] A user enters an empty Private Desk without Owner: meeting is created
- [x] Another User joins a Private Desk Owner at their desk: a meeting is created
  - [x] Desk Owner leaves: meeting is not ended
  - [x] Other user leaves: meeting is ended

metadata.pr_title: Prevent unscheduled meetings on private desk areas with only 1 user.
metadata.pr_body:
Modify unplanned meeting behavior for private desks: Private Desks only have unscheduled meetings if there are at least 2 Users on it.

Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/PDCT-96/investigate-improving-the-long-unscheduled-meeting-when-user-is-in

### Details

To support this new functionality, both the "unscheduled meeting creation" and "meeting deletion" methods had to be modified. Additionally, the definition of a SpaceUser being "`isInMeetingArea`" had to change to adapt to this new logic. A shared definition in the `MapArea` model unifies the logic.

- Changed meeting creation logic for private desks
  - Only private desks (not all walled desks) support meetings now
  - Require at least 2 participants to create an unplanned meeting in a private desk
  - Regular meeting areas still only require 1 participant
- Added `minimumParticipantsRequiredForUnplannedMeeting` property to MapArea
  - Returns 2 for private desks, 1 for other meeting areas
- Updated meeting ending logic
  - Unplanned meetings in private desks now end when participant count drops below 2
  - Other meeting types still end when all participants leave
- Updated what it means for a User to be "in a meeting area"
  - Some Areas are always in a "Meeting" - currently, only `MeetingRoom`

### Test Plan

- [x] User A enters a Meeting Room: a Meeting is created (doesn't break existing logic)
  - [x] User A leaves the Meeting Room: the Meeting ends (doesn't break existing logic)
- [x] User A and User B both enter a Meeting Room: a Meeting is created (doesn't break existing logic)
  - [x] User B leaves the Meeting Room: the Meeting does *not* end (doesn't break existing logic)
- [x] User A enters an open desk: a Meeting is *not* created (doesn't break existing logic)
- [x] User A enters a private (walled) desk: a Meeting is *not* created (new logic)
  - [x] User A leaves a private (walled) desk: nothing happens
- [x] User A and User B both enter a private (walled) desk: a Meeting is created (new logic)
  - [x] User B leaves the Meeting Room: the Meeting ends (doesn't break existing logic)

metadata.pr_body:
[VW-4412: Meeting room reentry issue causing unexpected meeting](https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/VW-4412/meeting-room-reentry-issue-causing-unexpected-meeting)

### Details

If you disconnect from a meeting room and rejoin while an unlocked meeting is occurring in the same meeting room, you are automatically added to the meeting when you join.

This PR adds a check to see if you're on the meeting participants list before keeping you in the meeting room. If you're not on the participants list, you're sent to your desk (or lobby if you don't have a desk).

metadata.pr_title: fix: account for notification banner height in floating UI element positioning (PDCT-571)
metadata.pr_body:
## Summary

Fixes issue where notification banner does not adjust the positioning of notification collapse/clear controls and inspection panels, causing them to overlap with the banner when it's visible.

## Changes Made

**1. FloatingInspectionPanel.tsx**
- Added import for BANNER_HEIGHT_PX from uiConfig.css
- Updated top offset calculation to include banner height (48px) when Repos.appFrame.isBannerShown is true
- Maintains existing logic for meeting overlay and video connection states

**2. NotificationsContainer.tsx**  
- Added import for BANNER_HEIGHT_PX from uiConfig.css
- Added isBannerShown prop to StyledContainer component
- Updated margin calculation to include banner offset when banner is visible
- Passes Repos.appFrame.isBannerShown to the styled component

## Technical Details

- Both components now check Repos.appFrame.isBannerShown to determine when the banner is visible
- When banner is shown, both components add BANNER_HEIGHT_PX (48px) to their respective top positioning calculations
- This ensures floating UI elements position below the banner instead of overlapping it
- Changes preserve existing behavior for meeting overlays and other UI states

## Testing

- [x] Verify notification panel positioning with banner visible
- [x] Verify inspection panel positioning with banner visible  
- [x] Verify normal positioning when banner is hidden
- [x] Test interaction with meeting overlays and video connections

## References

- Linear: PDCT-571 - Banner does not adjust notification collapse/clear placement
- Session GH-295: https://github.com/gathertown/claude-code-sessions/issues/295
- Slack Thread: https://gather-town.slack.com/archives/C0880SL4P6J/p1753920359768909?thread_ts=1753904343.604779&cid=C0880SL4P6J

metadata.pr_title: rename notification and clean up notification id
metadata.pr_body:
This stack is trying to accomplish the following:
- Update naming conventions to reflect what's in the [autobusy figjam](https://www.figma.com/board/f7Z4reblXZjwOBkribS2G6/Auto-Busy-for-External-Video-Calls?t=lTbSXFqPQ50KRYD1-0). Specifically we've split out autobusy from the external meeting flow. Autobusy means we automatically nav a user to a meeting room when an external meeting is detected. External meeting flow means a calendar event with an external meeting link will force participants to flip to busy + redirect to an external meeting provider.
- Add tests that cover behaviour E2E or when autobusy is turned off
- Fix a bunch of bugs to make behaviour feel more predictable

Simplify notification by using a static id (since we're always pushing a static notification).

### Test Plan

- [x] Mark this box if automated tests would suffice for the test plan (preferred)

metadata.pr_title: Close av issue report modal immediately on clicking send
metadata.pr_body:
Linear: https://linear.app/gather-town/issue/ENG-XXXX

Improves the issue reporting flow in AutoGrapesService to prevent duplicate reports and provide better user feedback.

### Details

- Refactored the report issue action flow to:
  - Capture current issues before clearing them
  - Close the notification immediately to prevent duplicate submissions
  - Send the report in the background with the captured issues
- Added a new `sendReportWithIssues` method that works with a provided list of issues
  - Allows reporting issues that have already been cleared from the current state
- Fixed notification handling in success/failure scenarios:
  - Success notification no longer checks for existing notification ID
  - Failure notification creates a new notification ID rather than reusing the existing one
  - Added cleanup of failure notification when retrying

### Test Plan

- [ ] Mark this box if automated tests would suffice for the test plan (preferred)

Or, if you can't be 100% confident through automated checks, delete ☝️the line above and write out a manual test plan. Changes needing to be performed by end users should remain unchecked until they are tested:

- [ ] Trigger an audio/video issue notification
- [ ] Click "Report issue" and verify the notification closes immediately
- [ ] Verify the success toast appears after sending
- [ ] Force a failure scenario and verify the failure notification appears
- [ ] Test the "Try again" button on the failure notification
- [ ] Verify no duplicate reports are sent when clicking multiple times

metadata.pr_title: fix: get rid of unnecessary FORCE_ENVIRONMENT
metadata.pr_body:
Standardize environment variable usage from `FORCE_ENVIRONMENT` to `ENVIRONMENT` and add `--preserve-env` flag to doppler commands.

### Details

- Renamed `FORCE_ENVIRONMENT` to `ENVIRONMENT` in workflow files and CLI commands
  - Simplifies environment variable handling by using a single variable
- Added `--preserve-env` flag to doppler commands
  - Ensures environment variables are properly preserved when running nested doppler commands
- Fixed conditional artifact uploads in test.yml
  - Changed `if: always()` to `if: ! cancelled()` to prevent uploads when workflows are cancelled
- Removed environment override logic in gather-cli migrate command
  - Allows for migrating multiple DBs at the same time without environment conflicts
